name: Boots & Bling - End of Year Banquet
description:
Get ready to kick up your boots and shine at the End of Year Student Leadership Banquet! Join us as we celebrate the hard work, dedication, and achievements of our student leaders who have made a lasting impact on campus this year.
This Boots & Bling-themed evening will be filled with recognition, camaraderie, and a little Southern sparkle! Enjoy a night of awards, dinner, and entertainment as we reflect on a fantastic year and look ahead to what’s next.
Dress in your best Western glam—whether that’s cowboy boots with a little glitter, denim and diamonds, or your favorite country-chic attire.
Don't miss this unforgettable night of appreciation and fun! RSVP by March 14th, 2025, to secure your spot

description: Demo Kitchen: Mason Jar SaladsLooking for a quick, healthy meal you can grab on the go? Come learn how to make Mason Jar Salads! Customize with your favorite ingredients for a portable, delicious option you’ll love!UNIVERSITY RECREATIONEvent Type: Demonstration KitchenMeeting Location: UREC Demo Kitchen Sign-up Here

name: Mental Health First Aid
description:
MHFA is an 8-hour training is a national public education program that introduces participants to risk factors and warning signs of mental illnesses and substance use, builds understanding of their impact, and overviews common supports.This course demonstrates how to offer initial help in a mental health crisis and connect persons to the appropriate professional, peer, social, and self-help care. 
 
To register for these sessions, please complete the form found here. Registration is REQUIRED. Walk-ins will not be able to attend.
*** Participants must complete 2 hours of pre-work and attend the full 6 hours of the instructor-led training to earn their certificate.
host: Center for Wellness Promotion, Health and Wellbeing, The Health Education Leadership and Prevention Certificate

Register Here

name: Jamil Niner Student Pantry: Tuesday Volunteer Shift  |  10:30am – 12:45pm
description:
Volunteer Shifts:
The Jamil Niner Student Pantry assists UNC Charlotte students and faculty/staff who are having challenges accessing food regularly. Through volunteering, you will be working with the pantry leadership team to provide healthy, culturally appropriate, and emergency foods to students, faculty, and staff on campus. Volunteer activities may include, but are not limited to: checking shoppers in and out, assisting with pantry upkeep, stocking and sorting food, garden work, and other various activities to help run the pantry. Please wear closed-toed shoes and comfortable clothing when volunteering at the food pantry. Enter through the front door and proceed to the conference room for volunteer check-in. 
If you are unable to stay for the duration of the volunteer shift, please notify a team member before leaving your shift. 
Questions? Email ninerpantry@charlotte.edu.

name: Establishing your Ethics
description:
How do leaders make tough choices? What is the difference between ethics, values and integrity? In this interactive workshop, participants discuss how choices are made and will learn the seven steps and ten rules of ethical decision-making.
 
This workshop counts towards the Leadership/Ethics.
host: Programs in Leadership and Organizational Training

name: Charlotte Parent Organization- Family Fun Day
description:
The Charlotte Parent Organization is hosting a Family Fun Day (April 21st, 2025 at 1-4 pm) at the Star Quad. This event's purpose is for UNC Charlotte parents and their children to enjoy fun activities which promote and foster a community that supports parents on campus. This event will help UNC Charlotte parents to connect and learn about the resources that are currently available on campus and the resources that we strive to provide. These fun activities will include water activities, toddler play area, racing obstacles, and a science fun booth! Additionally, we are partnering with the Jamil Student Pantry by accepting baby items (diapers, wipes, formula, etc.).
We are in need of volunteers that would like to facilitate some of these activities in order to have a successful event!
Contact Allison Stadick (astadick@charlotte.edu) for more information

name: Accountability Groups Spring 2025 - Tuesdays at 4:00
description:
<!--StartFragment -->
Ever heard of body doubling?
Body doubling, also known as parallel working, is a productivity strategy where two or more people work on something independently but in the same space. Some students find they are better able to focus and get more done when they are studying alongside someone else studying.
 
What are Accountability Groups?
Accountability Groups meet weekly for 75 minutes and are facilitated by student leaders. The groups are designed to capitalize on the idea of body doubling by helping members practice productive study habits, connect them with peers, and provide dedicated time to work on individual tasks.
 
Join an Accountability Group through Connect! You can sign up as the semester goes on or ask to be placed in the same group weekly.
 
The group that meets on Mondays at 5:30pm is reserved for students with ADHD and ADHD-like experiences.
<!--EndFragment -->

name: ASSP Student Section On-Campus Meeting
description:
Hello! We are the American Society of Safety Professionals Student Section. We are affiliated with the local ASSP Tarheel Chapter and our organization is designed for students who are pursuing a career in the safety, health and environmental fields. ASSP seeks to provide additional opportunities for students to learn more about their careers, and interact with safety professionals both on and off campus. These are our monthly (ish) meetings to discuss what's happening in the organization and help plan upcoming events. Some of these meetings may even have guest speakers from the industry!
 
*Alternate location is SMITH 218

name: Annual Health Psychology Research Showcase
description:
Hello!
We are so very excited for the second Annual Health Psychology Research Showcase.  This is a half-day showcase in which the faculty and students of the Health Psychology Ph.D. program will give poster presentations on their work.
This showcase will also feature a panel of Alumni who will share their experience in the program and both their academic and professional trajectories. 
Refreshments will be provided. 

 
This event is meant to be fun! This is intended to be a low-stakes celebration of our program and the work we do! This showcase helps open the floor for collaboration across members of the program and to share the work we do with those interested in Health Psychology. This showcase provides space to engage with members in our program and community in a fun way! This will also provide an excellent opportunity for students to practice giving poster talks, receive feedback, and for prospective students to see what this program is all about. This event will be held on campus, at the Student Union in rooms 262 (panel) and 261 (posters and refreshments). Please RSVP to this event!

name: Wednesday Night Community Group
description:
Community Group is a great way to make friends that feel like family while also being in an environment that encourages deepening your relationship with God! Community Groups are for people who desire to live life and do life in a Biblical community. These groups meet weekly and rotate between Family Nights and Mission Nights.




 
Family Nights: a time to gather, worship, encourage one another, and grow through prayer, the Bible, and song.




Mission Nights: a space with people in your community group to either share the gospel with people on campus, eat dinner with people who don’t know Jesus, or do a fun activity to show people who Jesus is as you model a life transformed by the gospel!

name: Reed Gold Mine Portable Radio Event
description: Parks on the Air is a program where radio operators go to state parks, historic sites, trails, etc. and operate, and thousands of other operators try to make a contact with them, and are rewarded with awards and personal achievements. As a club we will go to the Reed Gold Mine and operate during the "Support your parks" weekend where there will be a significant amount of Ham radio activity. If you want the opportunity to make long distance ham radio contacts, (All across the country, and possibly even the world!) now's the time to do it! We will be using a homemade antenna to make the contacts, so don't miss it!
host: Amateur Radio Club at UNC Charlotte

name: Opioid First Aid Training
location: The Waddell Center for Student Health and Wellbeing Room 293
description:
An opioid overdose can happen to anyone, at any time.
 
This FREE one-hour course will provide you with a basic understanding of contributors and risk factors of Opioid Use Disorder, how to recognize the signs/symptoms of a suspected or known opioid overdose, and how to administer/access the opioid reversal medication NARCAN® (naloxone HCL) Nasal Spray.
Designed for all students, faculty, and staff, including lay rescuers and healthcare professionals. 
 
The course is affiliated with The Discover Your Wellness Passport Program and provides a certificate upon completion.
 
*Registration is required for this training. Registration closes one week before the training date. To register, use this link.
You will not be permitted to attend this training without properly registering. Space is limited
host: Center for Wellness Promotion, The Health Education Leadership and Prevention Certificate

name: Jamil Niner Student Pantry: Thursday Volunteer Shift  | 12:30pm – 2:45pm
description:
Volunteer Shifts:
The Jamil Niner Student Pantry assists UNC Charlotte students and faculty/staff who are having challenges accessing food regularly. Through volunteering, you will be working with the pantry leadership team to provide healthy, culturally appropriate, and emergency foods to students, faculty, and staff on campus. Volunteer activities may include, but are not limited to: checking shoppers in and out, assisting with pantry upkeep, stocking and sorting food, garden work, and other various activities to help run the pantry. Please wear closed-toed shoes and comfortable clothing when volunteering at the food pantry. Enter through the front door and proceed to the conference room for volunteer check-in. 
If you are unable to stay for the duration of the volunteer shift, please notify a team member before leaving your shift. 
Questions? Email ninerpantry@charlotte.edu.

name: Teach Geology at the Girl Scout Spring Encampment: "Camp Rocks"
location: Dale Earnhardt Environmental Leadership Campus at Oak Springs
description:
Join Us for the Girl Scout's Spring Encampment!
Date: Saturday, April 5th
Location: Dale Earnhardt Environmental Leadership Campus: 1919 Turnersburg Hwy, Statesville, NC 28625 (carpools can be organized)
Participants: Approximately 100 Girl Scouts (1st to 12th grade)
Lunch: Provided for volunteers!
Schedule:

Morning Sessions: 10:00 AM & 11:00 AM
Afternoon Sessions: 2:00 PM & 3:00 PM

Each session will last 45 minutes, with around 40 scouts per session. You can choose to help with the morning sessions, afternoon sessions, or both!
Volunteer Shifts:

Morning Shift: Assist Dr. Reynolds with setting up stations, and run the 10:00 AM and 11:00 AM sessions. Break for lunch afterward.
Afternoon Shift: Join us for lunch, then help with the 2:00 PM and 3:00 PM sessions, and assist with breakdown and packing up.

Carpooling: We will create a email group with the morning and afternoon volunteers so we can carpool. It is about an hour from campus.
Sign-Up: This is the sign-up sheet for the event
host: GEO Club - Geology and Earth Sciences Organization, The Society of Sigma Gamma Epsilon

name: UNC Charlotte Robot Rumble 2025
description:
Come see combat robot fighting on UNC Charlotte campus! Expect sparks to be flying from 10:00 AM to 6:30 PM. We will have 48 robots battling in a double elimination tournament. The robots fight in a 8 foot cage of bulletproof glass and metal. Robots fight until one robot can not move anymore, or until a fight goes to judges after 2 minutes. See photos of last year's fight at our website! Stop by any time during the day to see exciting robot battles for free! The event is also free for non-students, and a great activity for families of all ages.
 
See all the exciting upcoming North Carolina Science festival events here.
 
Send any questions to charlottecombatrobotclub@gmail.com

name: Stop the Bleed - 1 Hour Course
location: Waddell Center for Student Health & Wellbeing - Room 293
description:
Stop The Bleed
Life-threatening bleeding injuries can happen anywhere at any time. 
This FREE 1-hour course will teach you to recognize life-threatening bleeding and how to intervene quickly through three techniques: (1) how to apply direct pressure to a wound; (2) how to pack a wound to control bleeding; (3) how to correctly apply a tourniquet.  
Designed for all students, faculty, and staff, including lay rescuers and healthcare professionals. Register for class at StudentHealth.charlotte.edu/classes
The course is affiliated with The Discover your Wellness Passport Program, the H.E.L.P. Certificate Program, and provides a certificate upon completion.
host: Student Health Center, The Health Education Leadership and Prevention Certificate

name: Coffee and Conversations: Navigating the New Media Landscape
description:
To conclude our series Behind the Screens: Exploring Social Media Ownership and Digital Privacy, join us for an informal event focused on the pressing topics shaping our media landscape. Engage in open conversations with fellow students, faculty, and staff about media ownership, digital literacy, censorship, digital privacy, and future directions of our media landscape. Share reflections and exchange ideas from your life, work, and research while connecting with others.
Attendees can also learn more about the Critical Media Literacy Collaborative and opportunities to get involved. Coffee and tea will be provided. Open to all students, faculty, and staff.

name: Tuesday Night Community Group
description:
Community Group is a great way to make friends that feel like family while also being in an environment that encourages deepening your relationship with God! Community Groups are for people who desire to live life and do life in a Biblical community. These groups meet weekly and rotate between Family Nights and Mission Nights.




Family Nights: a time to gather, worship, encourage one another, and grow through prayer, the Bible, and song.




Mission Nights: a space with people in your community group to either share the gospel with people on campus, eat dinner with people who don’t know Jesus, or do a fun activity to show people who Jesus is as you model a life transformed by the gospel!

name: Accountability Groups Spring 2025 - Tuesdays at 2:30
description:
<!--StartFragment -->
Ever heard of body doubling?
Body doubling, also known as parallel working, is a productivity strategy where two or more people work on something independently but in the same space. Some students find they are better able to focus and get more done when they are studying alongside someone else studying.
 
What are Accountability Groups?
Accountability Groups meet weekly for 75 minutes and are facilitated by student leaders. The groups are designed to capitalize on the idea of body doubling by helping members practice productive study habits, connect them with peers, and provide dedicated time to work on individual tasks.
 
Join an Accountability Group through Connect! You can sign up as the semester goes on or ask to be placed in the same group weekly.
 
The group that meets on Mondays at 5:30pm is reserved for students with ADHD and ADHD-like experiences.
<!--EndFragment -->

name: Mallard Creek Stream Clean
description:
Join us for this spring's stream cleanup! Like in previous semesters, we will be cleaning a very short distance from campus on a portion of Mallard Creek. Our parking and meeting spot is the parking lot of Kirk Farm Fields Park. Gloves, grabbers, and some waders will be provided by Charlotte Stormwater. Please wear sturdy footwear and dress appropriately for a morning navigating the near creek environment, brush, floodplain, etc. Most people will not be in the creek but on the banks and around the greenway. 
We hope to see you then! Morning snacks provided for cleanup crew! Feel free to invite friends; bring some water and a good attitude and we'll all have fun keeping our community cleaner!
host: GEO Club - Geology and Earth Sciences Organization, The Society of Sigma Gamma Epsilon

name: Write Now!
description:
Are you working on a piece of writing? Could you benefit from some extra accountability and motivation to make progress? Then join us for Write Now!Modeled on the popular Shut Up and Write! program, each Write Now! session features two hours of structured writing time for you to focus on making progress on your writing. Participating in structured writing times benefits graduate and postdoctoral writers by allowing them to strengthen writing habits, make meaningful progress on writing projects, and improve attitudes about writing (Cayley et al., forthcoming; Tremblay-Wragg et al., 2021).
Whether you're writing an article, working on a dissertation chapter, preparing to defend your thesis, or just trying to get some work done, Write Now! is right for you!
 
Facilitator: Caitlin BrabbleRose
Register Here
host: The Center for Graduate Life and Learning

name: Loraine Lab Data Visualization Workshop
description:
Hello everyone,
Please join us in this upcoming workshop led by the Loraine Lab on Wednesday, April 9th at 3pm, BINF room 408. Refreshments Provided.
 

Are you preparing a research presentation and looking for ways to make your genomic data visually compelling? We've got you covered!
We'll dive into the powerful tool IGB (Integrated Genome Browser) and show you how to:

Visually analyze your genomic data
Produce high-quality figures

This hands-on workshop is perfect for anyone looking to enhance their presentations and make their genomic data stand out. Please bring the genomic data that you'd like to visualize and make a figure for, and your laptops.

Don't miss this opportunity to transform your research presentations!
 
Looking forward to seeing you soon,
BiAS

During the tour, we’ll hear from expert speakers on the critical role that property management plays in enhancing the value of commercial real estate. Whether you're an investor, developer, or CRE enthusiast, this event is a great way to expand your knowledge and network with fellow professionals.

name: Formatting and Submitting Your Thesis or Dissertation
description:
Are you planning to submit your thesis or dissertation sometime this or next semester? Attend this session to have all of your questions about formatting, defense, and submission procedures answered! 
These virtual workshops are offered approximately every two weeks and are *essential* for a stress-free graduation.
 
Register for Zoom Link
Presenter: Michelle HypkiPlease note: Our virtual presentations are designed to foster interpersonal interaction, just as a face-to-face meeting would do. For that reason, no digital note-takers, recorders, or other AI-driven programs are permitted in our Zoom workshops. Thank you.
host: The Center for Graduate Life and Learning

name: Adjusting to American Culture: Talent + Fashion Show
description:
Where: Atkins 146
 
When: 3:00 - 4:00pmThe Adjusting to American Culture events are designed to support international students who have recently moved to the United States and are experiencing cultural challenges. Each event provides students from all over the world a chance to connect, learn, and share in a casual, relaxed, and social environment.
 
For the third Adjusting to American Culture spring '25 event, international students will be given a platform to show off their unique talents, providing their friends with an authentic, personal glimpse into their home countries. There are rich traditions all around the world, and whether yours include singing, poetry, dancing, or something else entirely, we invite you to come share them with your fellow international students in a relaxed, fun atmosphere. Coffee and snacks will be provided!
 
Register Here
Facilitator: Sharmeen Hatimbhai, Center for Graduate Life and Learning Global Niner

name: Reinventing the Dollar: How Tech is Shaping the Future of Money
description: Niner Finances Presents... Reinventing the Dollar. We explore the cutting-edge advancements reshaping the financial landscape. Discover how innovations like blockchain, cryptocurrencies, and digital banking are revolutionizing transactions and investment strategies. Gain insights into the future of money management, from mobile payments to AI-driven financial planning. Whether you're a fintech enthusiast or simply curious about the evolving financial landscape, this workshop offers valuable perspectives on navigating the digital economy and harnessing the power of financial technology.

name: The Low Down on Credit Management
description: Niner Finances Presents...The Low Down on Credit Management. Learn about credit cards and practical strategies for managing credit wisely, understanding credit scores, and improving financial health. Explore effective debt management techniques and discover how to navigate credit responsibly. Whether you're new to credit or seeking to enhance your current credit record, this workshop will provide valuable insights and actionable steps toward financial success.

name: Get Savvy with Saving & Investing
description: Niner Finances presents... Saving & Investing. Navigating the realm of saving and investing can feel daunting, especially with the shift away from traditional employer-based financial security. Yet, this change has ushered in fresh opportunities and innovative approaches to managing finances. The days of relying solely on a lifelong job and a generous pension are fading. Today, achieving goals and pursuing passions necessitates a deeper understanding of saving and investing. Embracing this reality, individuals are empowered to explore diverse strategies to secure their financial future beyond conventional means.

name: Paddles & Stars - Whitewater Rafting and Camping
location: TBD based on weather and river levels
description:
Join Venture Outdoor Leadership for an overnight trip like no other!  We'll explore a North Carolina river in rafts, following the water while enjoying the views, learning how to work together as a team, and honing the craftsmanship of team paddling.  Designed for both beginners and experienced rafters, our adventure trip leaders will guide and teach along the way.
While no experience is necessary, comfort being submerged in water is required. While we don't plan on capsizes, they may happen. The pre-trip meeting will include a water-comfort assessment in the Belk Gym pool. If you have any questions or concerns, please reach out to our office at venturedept@charlotte.edu
Costs include: Transportation to/from campus; meals; equipment; technical clothing (e.g. rain jackets); instruction. 

Student - $95
Faculty/Staff/Alumni - $110
Community - $150

Required Pre-Trip Meeting: Wed, April 9, 4:00pm - 6:00pm
Registration due by Wed, April 9 at 12pm
https://venture.charlotte.edu/adventure-trips/trip-registration

name: Walk In Hours
description:
Do you have a question about your personal finances? Questions about credit, debt, investing, budgeting, saving, etc?
We can help! 
Join Niner Finances (The Financial Literacy and well-being department) for our virtual and in-person walk-in hours. 
None of the dates and times for our walk-in hours work for you? Let us know!

name: Accountability Groups Spring 2025 - Wednesday at 2:30
description:
<!--StartFragment -->
Ever heard of body doubling?
Body doubling, also known as parallel working, is a productivity strategy where two or more people work on something independently but in the same space. Some students find they are better able to focus and get more done when they are studying alongside someone else studying.
 
What are Accountability Groups?
Accountability Groups meet weekly for 75 minutes and are facilitated by student leaders. The groups are designed to capitalize on the idea of body doubling by helping members practice productive study habits, connect them with peers, and provide dedicated time to work on individual tasks.
 
Join an Accountability Group through Connect! You can sign up as the semester goes on or ask to be placed in the same group weekly.
 
The group that meets on Mondays at 5:30pm is reserved for students with ADHD and ADHD-like experiences.
<!--EndFragment -->

location: Lucas Room in the Cone Center
description: Have you ever wanted to get involved, build community, explore your interests but don’t know where to start? Learn about the different ways to get involved on campus and how you can join or create your own organization. Aaaand seniors ever wonder what events are a MUST before you leave Charlotte?? location: Black Box theater in Robinson Hall
description: Come see The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee, a student-led musical full of humor, heart, and unexpected moments. Follow six quirky middle schoolers as they compete for the spelling championship, with plenty of laughs and heartfelt stories along the way. This production is entirely led by students, from the creative team to the performers, showcasing the incredible talent within our campus community. Admission is free for all students, so grab your friends and join us for an unforgettable evening of theater.

We invite student to come out on April 29th at 7pm in SAC Salons A-E to enjoy a fun night of music, dancing, and fun!

name: Business Etiquette Seminar
description: LOOKING FOR A GREAT INTERNSHIP NOW AND/OR FULL-TIME JOB UPON GRADUATION? WANT TO BRAND YOURSELF TO BE THE MOST SUCCESSFUL PROFESSIONAL VERSION OF YOURSELF? IF YES, YOU NEED TO ATTEND THE BUSINESS ETIQUETTE / PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT EVENT ON 4/8!!WHO SHOULD ATTEND?:  Any student interested in enhancing their career search and identifying a great paying internship and job opportunities WHAT? :  Business Etiquette / Professional Development Event – Training on Career Planning including Branding, Interview Skills, Career Paths, Networking, Internships and Meal Etiquette (Sponsored by Gamma Iota Sigma but open to all students) WHEN? :  Tuesday April 8th, 4 p.m. – 7 p.m. (Dinner Included*) WHERE?:  Cone Rm. #210A WHY?:       Professionals from Amwins will present on Internships and Career Paths available now as well as guidance on how to succeed in  your  career planning and attaining that perfect job! You will have an opportunity to meet, network with and connect moving forward with these hiring professionals!  This is an interactive event and there will be exciting prizes and a raffle for a $25 dining gift card! If you need to miss a class, please request approval from your instructor and we can confirm your attendance at the event.

name: Jamil Niner Student Pantry: Tuesday Volunteer Shift  |  12:30pm – 2:45pm
description:
Volunteer Shifts:
The Jamil Niner Student Pantry assists UNC Charlotte students and faculty/staff who are having challenges accessing food regularly. Through volunteering, you will be working with the pantry leadership team to provide healthy, culturally appropriate, and emergency foods to students, faculty, and staff on campus. Volunteer activities may include, but are not limited to: checking shoppers in and out, assisting with pantry upkeep, stocking and sorting food, garden work, and other various activities to help run the pantry. Please wear closed-toed shoes and comfortable clothing when volunteering at the food pantry. Enter through the front door and proceed to the conference room for volunteer check-in. 
If you are unable to stay for the duration of the volunteer shift, please notify a team member before leaving your shift. 
Questions? Email ninerpantry@charlotte.edu.

The YMCA of Greater Charlotte and Miracle League teamed up to give children with disabilities a chance to play baseball by creating the YMCA Miracle League through a generous financial contribution. They place children on a team of between 10 and 12 baseball players for games that last approximately one hour. Your job will to be to assist wherever help is needed and show compassion and kindness. Your job will to be to assist wherever help is needed and show compassion and kindness.

host: Student Involvement Office, Venture Outdoor Leadership

name: Write Now!
description:
Are you working on a piece of writing? Could you benefit from some extra accountability and motivation to make progress? Then join us for Write Now!Modeled on the popular Shut Up and Write! program, each Write Now! session features two hours of structured writing time for you to focus on making progress on your writing. Participating in structured writing times benefits graduate and postdoctoral writers by allowing them to strengthen writing habits, make meaningful progress on writing projects, and improve attitudes about writing (Cayley et al., forthcoming; Tremblay-Wragg et al., 2021).
Whether you're writing an article, working on a dissertation chapter, preparing to defend your thesis, or just trying to get some work done, Write Now! is right for you!
Facilitator: Candice Dsouza
Register Here
host: The Center for Graduate Life and Learning

name: DEMO KITCHEN: NO COOK CURRIED WRAPS

Along the way, we'll dive into the differences between animal-based protein and plant-based protein. Best of all, there's no cooking equipment required!UNIVERSITY RECREATIONEvent Type: Demonstration KitchenMeeting Location: UREC Demo Kitchen Sign-up Here

description:
Help unload donated household items, organize, and clean the donations, place the items on the sales floor, maintain the cleanliness and organization of the store, and assist customers with carry-outs after purchase.
Please wear enclosed shoes and comfortable clothes that can get dirty.  Shorts must be finger-tip length or longer.  Shirts must have sleeves.

name: Squeeze the Stress Away
description: Join RA Jackie and RA Liyah for Squeeze the Stress Away, a hands-on stress relief event designed to help you unwind before exams. You'll create your own stress balls using balloons and flour while learning quick mindfulness techniques to manage anxiety. Plus, grab self-care tips and uplifting affirmations to keep you motivated. Don't miss this chance to relax and recharge!

name: Anything that Rolls - Group Campus Bike Ride
location: Light Rail - UNC Charlotte - Main Station
description:
Join us for Anything that Rolls, a fun and relaxed group ride around campus! Whether you’re on a bike, skateboard, scooter, rollerblades, or anything else with wheels, this event is all about movement, community, and sustainability.
Lime has a limited number of electric bikes and scooters available for those who don't have one. Please complete the registration form on this page and indicate interest in a Lime device, first-come-first-served. Register for a device/ RSVP here: https://forms.gle/VKHukM5jn5p5QdBk9 
🚲 What to Expect:

A casual ride suitable for all experience levels
A chance to explore campus in a new way
Meet fellow riders
Help advocate for better micromobility on and around campus!

Bring your wheels, your friends, and let’s roll together toward a greener campus! 🌿✨
host: Business and Auxiliary Services, Charlotte Green Initiative, Campus Sustainability Alliance, Student Government Association, Sustainability

name: Bonfire Bites
description: Join RA Bhavana and Justin in the Laurel Hall Courtyard for a cozy evening of sweet treats and great company at our S’mores Social Night! We’ll gather around the fire, roast marshmallows to perfection, and enjoy classic s’mores with all the gooey goodness. Whether you're here to meet new friends, relax under the stars, or just indulge in some delicious snacks, this is the perfect chance to unwind and connect.

name: Knafeh Competition
description: Join us in an indulgent competition to see who makes it best!

name: Negotiating Your Employment Offer
description:
VirtualTime: 3:30pm - 4:30pmSalary negotiation is often an afterthought in the job search process. Some people find it to be a nerve-racking and sweat-inducing proposition, but it doesn't have to be. With preparation, practice, and data-based dialogue, you can work to ensure that you are being paid a fair and equitable salary based on your education, experience, and unique qualifications. This workshop will put your mind at ease and provide the tools necessary to undertake the salary negotiation process.
Register for Zoom link. Please note: Our virtual presentations are designed to foster interpersonal interaction, just as a face-to-face meeting would do. For that reason, no digital note-takers, recorders, or other AI-driven programs are permitted in our Zoom workshops. Thank you.
Facilitator: Brandi Ledermann
host: The Center for Graduate Life and Learning

name: Stop the Bleed
description: GPHA and Pulse Protectors are hosting a Stop the Bleed training! You will learn how to recognize life-threatening bleeding and how to intervene! This training is free and open to all. This is one of many events to kick off National Public Health Week 2025!
host: Graduate Public Health Association, Pulse Protectors at UNC Charlotte

name: Charlotte Parent Organization- Family Fun Day
description:
The Charlotte Parent Organization is hosting a Family Fun Day (April 21st, 2025 at 1-4 pm) at the Star Quad. This event's purpose is for UNC Charlotte parents and their children to enjoy fun activities which promote and foster a community that supports parents on campus. This event will help UNC Charlotte parents to connect and learn about the resources that are currently available on campus and the resources that we strive to provide. These fun activities will include water activities, toddler play area, racing obstacles, and a science fun booth! Additionally, we are partnering with the Jamil Student Pantry by accepting baby items (diapers, wipes, formula, etc.).
We are in need of volunteers that would like to facilitate some of these activities in order to have a successful event!
Contact Allison Stadick (astadick@charlotte.edu) for more information

name: Question, Persuade, Refer Suicide Prevention Training for Students
description:
QPR is a 90-minute training intended to foster a community of care by teaching individuals how to recognize the warning signs of suicide, including verbal, behavioral, and situational clues. The training provides guidelines on how to Question a person about suicidal thoughts, Persuade them to get help, and Refer them to campus and/or local resources.
Please use this link to register via zoom at least 48 hours in advance.

name: Charlotte Rocketry Club 2024-2025 Rocket
description: The Charlotte Rocketry Club creates an environment for students to learn, apply, and engage in aviation, aerospace, and rocketry. The organization has developed a project: to design, build, launch, and safely recover a Level 1 High Power Rocket (HPR) as a team. During the fall semester, students work with the sub-system team of their choosing and begin designing the club rocket. Students will learn how to use Open Rocket to evaluate their designs and then move forward to choosing supplies. During the Spring semester, students then begin the assembly of each individual sub-system until the club as a whole is ready for the final assembly on launch day at the end of the semester. Students will then have the opportunity to travel to Dalzell South Carolina to launch the club rocket in April 2025.

name: The LatinX Student Union's 4th Annual Gala
description:
The LatinX Student Union Annual Gala is a signature event dedicated to highlighting and celebrating the achievements of students committed to driving meaningful change in Latino communities. Rooted in our mission to serving communities in need, this gala serves as a space to honor student achievements, recognize the transformative work of our peers, and foster connections that inspire continued service and advocacy for Latino communities.
This special evening highlights the community impact efforts of current students at UNC Charlotte, honors our graduating seniors, and brings together current and former LXSU leaders to celebrate our shared commitment to driving meaningful change for Latino communities.

description:
Join us for an unforgettable evening at the SHPE Gala 2025, a night dedicated to honoring the achievements, resilience, and excellence of our SHPE Familia. This formal celebration will highlight the incredible impact of our members, recognize outstanding leaders, and bring together students, professionals, alumni, and industry partners under one roof.
Enjoy a night filled with elegance, inspiring speeches, awards, networking opportunities, and vibrant cultural celebration. From a delicious dinner to live entertainment and heartfelt moments, the SHPE Gala is more than an event—it's a tribute to our shared journey and the bright future we are building together.

name: Personal Branding
description:
Depending on what you (or other people) have shared about yourself, society has used it to develop an idea of who you are. This is your personal brand. Do you like your brand? What does your brand say about you? Could it say more? Attend this workshop to develop your personal brand through an exploration of values, motivations, goals, and aspirations. Attendees will learn techniques for social media usage and in-person networking strategies. Walk away with practical tips and suggestions for changing how the world sees you! 
 
This workshop counts towards the Skill Building PILOT Credit.
host: Programs in Leadership and Organizational Training

name: Thursday Night Community Group
description:
Community Group is a great way to make friends that feel like family while also being in an environment that encourages deepening your relationship with God! Community Groups are for people who desire to live life and do life in a Biblical community. These groups meet weekly and rotate between Family Nights and Mission Nights.




Family Nights: a time to gather, worship, encourage one another, and grow through prayer, the Bible, and song.

name: Accountability Groups Spring 2025 - Tuesdays at 4:00
description:
<!--StartFragment -->
Ever heard of body doubling?
Body doubling, also known as parallel working, is a productivity strategy where two or more people work on something independently but in the same space. Some students find they are better able to focus and get more done when they are studying alongside someone else studying.
 
What are Accountability Groups?
Accountability Groups meet weekly for 75 minutes and are facilitated by student leaders. The groups are designed to capitalize on the idea of body doubling by helping members practice productive study habits, connect them with peers, and provide dedicated time to work on individual tasks.
 
Join an Accountability Group through Connect! You can sign up as the semester goes on or ask to be placed in the same group weekly.
 
The group that meets on Mondays at 5:30pm is reserved for students with ADHD and ADHD-like experiences.
<!--EndFragment -->

name: 2025 Graduate Research Symposium
description:
WHAT IS THE GRADUATE RESEARCH SYMPOSIUM?
The Symposium is an interdisciplinary graduate student-run conference that allows graduate and professional students to showcase their research.
WHO CAN PARTICIPATE IN THE SYMPOSIUM?
UNC Charlotte graduate students are invited to present their research. Research from any field is welcome to be submitted. We have great hopes of highlighting the important work of graduate students at UNC Charlotte and enjoying a one-day opportunity to network and honor each other's achievements. 
CAN I PRESENT RESEARCH THAT I HAVE PRESENTED ELSEWHERE ALREADY?
Yes! GRS is designed to showcase the wonderful work being done by UNC Charlotte graduate students. So even if you've presented your work elsewhere, we welcome you to submit it to GRS and share it with the UNC Charlotte community.
HOW DO I SUBMIT AN ABSTRACT?
Please refer to the following documents in preparation for writing your abstract. 
Abstract Rubric
Abstract Writing Presentation
 
Directions to submit: 
To submit an abstract, Go to Conference Management Toolkit (CMT), register an account, and search for GRS2025 or Graduate Research Symposium 2025 under all conferences. Click on create a new submission, and skip Edit Conflicts of Interest.
Questions? Reach out to the GPSG Vice President at gpsgvicepresident@charlotte.edu.
host: The Center for Graduate Life and Learning

name: Write Now!
description:
Are you working on a piece of writing? Could you benefit from some extra accountability and motivation to make progress? Then join us for Write Now!Modeled on the popular Shut Up and Write! program, each Write Now! session features two hours of structured writing time for you to focus on making progress on your writing. Participating in structured writing times benefits graduate and postdoctoral writers by allowing them to strengthen writing habits, make meaningful progress on writing projects, and improve attitudes about writing (Cayley et al., forthcoming; Tremblay-Wragg et al., 2021).
Whether you're writing an article, working on a dissertation chapter, preparing to defend your thesis, or just trying to get some work done, Write Now! is right for you!
Facilitator: Candice Dsouza
Register Here

name: TLC (Thai/Lao/Cambodian) New Year
description: Our Thai, Lao, and Cambodian (TLC) New Year celebration at UNC Charlotte helps to showcase some of the rich cultural traditions of Southeast Asia. The event features live performances (music + dance,) traditional shaving cream and water games (typically enjoyed at TLC,)  paper lantern making, and other manners of celebration. This event is open to all and attendees can enjoy authentic cuisine, participate in traditional games, and learn about the significance of TLC New Year. Traditional attire, customs, and interactive activities help bring awareness of this beautiful culture that a lot of people may not know about. Our purpose is to foster community engagement and appreciation for the diverse heritage of SE Asian cultures.

name: Love Bloom with the Neos
description: This event educates our peers and other students about the importance of flower maintenance, how to better care for them, gardening benefits, and how they can serve a greater purpose in your everyday life. It is a way for everyone to bond while also having real-life examples of what they are learning about. Since it is during the springtime, it is a great way to make connections with the community. Love Blooms with the Neos will provide an influential and empowering environment that will benefit our campus and community. Through this event, we are incorporating one our main principles, Love. We believe we can foster a positive culture of individuals who may consider incorporating gardening into their lives. As a sisterhood, one of our main goals is to create community involvement and leadership, and we believe that by having this event, we can achieve this. Additionally, LTA not only paves the gift of gaining valuable knowledge but also fosters a sense of self-love towards everyone around. LTA is committed to making a difference all around our community.

name: STEAM Innovation Expo
description:
Calling all interested faculty, students, staff, student groups, businesses, and community partners! The 2025 UNC Charlotte STEAM Innovation Expo is seeking exhibitors, volunteers, and official sponsors.
We are thrilled the UNC Charlotte STEAM Innovation Expo as part of the 2025 NC Science Festival is back! In 2024, we hosted over 9,000 people on campus. The 2025 Expo will be Sunday, April 27, from 12:00 pm until 4:00 pm.  The STEAM Expo will take place on the UNC Charlotte plaza between Mebane Hall (Cato College of Education), the College of Health and Human Services Building, Barnhardt Student Activities Center, and Woodward Hall. 
The UNC Charlotte Center for STEM Education, UNC Charlotte STEM departments, and community stakeholders will facilitate events focused on engaging and interactive STEM learning opportunities. Through hands-on activities, STEM talks, lab tours, nature experiences, exhibits and performances, the UNC Charlotte STEAM Expo engages a wide range of public audiences while inspiring future generations.
The UNC Charlotte STEAM Innovation Expo is sponsored by the Center for STEM Education and the North Carolina Science Festival. Please contact us at stem-precollege@charlotte.edu if you have any questions. We look forward to your participation!

name: Dance Marathon-Main Event
description:

This year's Ninerthon invites you to join Buzz, Woody, and the whole gang on an unforgettable journey "To Infinity and Beyond." Together, we'll dance, celebrate, and support a cause that makes a real difference, all while embracing the boundless imagination and camaraderie of Disney Pixar's Toy Story.
Whether you're a Space Ranger ready to take on the stars or a loyal cowboy with a big heart, this event promises endless fun, laughter, and memories. Come as your favorite character, enjoy themed activities, and remind yourself what it means to believe in the impossible—all while rallying to support a cause that brings hope and joy to children in need.
Are you ready to embark on this heartwarming adventure? Let's make every moment count as we reach for the stars and beyond!

name: ACM Weekly Meeting
description:
For Spring 2025, ACM will meet every Wednesday evening in Woodward 154 from 5:30 to 7:00. Students and prospective members should always feel free to drop in late or leave early as needed.
During the first half of our meeting, we usually spend some time socializing and checking in with our peers, since networking is such an important professional skill to develop. For the rest of the time, we'll look at programming/coding problem together and split into pair programming groups to try and come up with solutions collaboratively. We will also set aside some time to discuss current topics and interests in tech and/or spend additional time workshopping resumes or interview skills with our peers.

name: Jamil Niner Student Pantry: Tuesday Volunteer Shift  |  10:30am – 12:45pm
description:
Volunteer Shifts:
The Jamil Niner Student Pantry assists UNC Charlotte students and faculty/staff who are having challenges accessing food regularly. Through volunteering, you will be working with the pantry leadership team to provide healthy, culturally appropriate, and emergency foods to students, faculty, and staff on campus. Volunteer activities may include, but are not limited to: checking shoppers in and out, assisting with pantry upkeep, stocking and sorting food, garden work, and other various activities to help run the pantry. Please wear closed-toed shoes and comfortable clothing when volunteering at the food pantry. Enter through the front door and proceed to the conference room for volunteer check-in. 
If you are unable to stay for the duration of the volunteer shift, please notify a team member before leaving your shift. 
Questions? Email ninerpantry@charlotte.edu.

description:
This semester, we are hosting a Diabetes Tech Seminar! Join the Diabetes Link at UNC Charlotte and representatives from the biomedical technology field to learn about diabetes management technology and how you can get involved!

This is a great opportunity to network with diabetes companies for potential internships and jobs! 

Entry Information: To get in you will need to get you FREE ticket here: https://bit.ly/dltechseminar
host: The Diabetes Link at UNC Charlotte

name: Accountability Groups Spring 2025 - Mondays at 5:30
description:
Ever heard of body doubling?
Body doubling, also known as parallel working, is a productivity strategy where two or more people work on something independently but in the same space. Some students find they are better able to focus and get more done when they are studying alongside someone else studying.
 
What are Accountability Groups?
Accountability Groups meet weekly for 75 minutes and are facilitated by student leaders. The groups are designed to capitalize on the idea of body doubling by helping members practice productive study habits, connect them with peers, and provide dedicated time to work on individual tasks.
 
Join an Accountability Group through Connect! You can sign up as the semester goes on or ask to be placed in the same group weekly.
 
This group that meets on Mondays at 5:30pm is reserved for students with ADHD and ADHD-like experiences.

name: Lambdasada
description: The brothers of Lambda Theta Phi Latin Fraternity, Inc. are thrilled to host our annual Lambdasada event, a celebration of culture, connection, and community at UNC Charlotte. This event is more than just a gathering; it’s a passionate effort to create opportunities, build meaningful relationships, and provide a sense of belonging for Latino students on campus. While our focus is on fostering a strong Latino community, Lambdasada is open to everyone, inviting people of all backgrounds to come together and experience the vibrancy of Latino culture. We hope to create a welcoming and uplifting space where students can feel supported, inspired, and reenergized in the face of a challenging academic environment.
host: Lambda Theta Phi Latin Fraternity, Inc.

name: End-of-Year Celebration
description:
Join the Commercial Real Estate Society for our highly anticipated End-of-Year Celebration, proudly sponsored by Insite, who will also deliver the keynote address. This special event will feature an insightful discussion on diverse topics within the real estate industry, providing attendees with invaluable knowledge and perspectives.
We'll take a moment to honor our graduating members, celebrating their academic achievements with the presentation of cords and stoles. Additionally, we'll shine a spotlight on those who have successfully secured full-time positions or internships in the field—an acknowledgment of their hard work and dedication.This is more than just a celebration; it's an incredible networking opportunity. Attendees will have the chance to connect with our distinguished keynote speaker and notable figures within Charlotte's thriving commercial real estate market, many of whom have been integral to the Society's events throughout the year.Don't miss this remarkable occasion to learn, celebrate, and build meaningful connections in the industry. See you there!

name: Procrastination Workshop Series
location: Visualization Lab, J. Murrey Atkins Library, 2nd floor
description:
Struggling with procrastination? One part of you knows what you should be doing, and another part of you still puts it off until the last minute or doesn't do it at all, so you're left feeling panicked, guilty, or frustrated with yourself. Join us for a workshop addressing common causes of procrastination, including perfectionism and external pressures. We will explore the thoughts, behaviors, and emotions that often prevent us from being as productive and on-task as we would like. We will discuss practical tools to improve time management and accountability, along with ways to reframe your mindset and manage the emotions that come up with procrastination.
 
This is a 3 part workshop happening on 3 consecutive Thursdays in April. To receive the most benefits, please plan to attend all 3 workshop. Sign up for the other session:
April 10, 4-5pm 
April 24, 4-5pm
host: Counseling and Psychological Services, J. Murrey Atkins Library

name: The Power of Postprints in Academic Writing
description:
Finishing up an article? Great - but are you taking advantage of the postprint? Be honest: have you even heard of a postprint before? Well, now’s the time to learn!
Join Atkins Library experts Jeff McAdams and Savannah Lake to learn about the complete life cycle of your article, from preprint to the final version, and how postprints specifically can amplify your research and extend its reach. Coffee and snacks will be served!
 
Register Here
(Image: British Museum, CC BY-NC-SA 4.0)
host: The Center for Graduate Life and Learning

name: Presidents' Leadership Workshop
description:
This workshop will help you learn how to lead your student organization, delegate tasks and authority, and learn about the resources and benefits available to you as a registered student organization. This workshop typically runs 1 hour and 15 minutes, leaving 15 minutes at the end for conversation and questions. Be ready to participate and share the great things your organization is doing!
 
This workshop is required as a part of the annual registration requirements for student organizations.
 
Contact acholula@charlotte.edu for any and all questions regarding this workshop.

name: AfroBITS Game Night
description: Join Us at a social game night with AfroBITS! Enjoy fun games, food, and laughter! See you at the last AfroBITS meeting of the semester!

name: The State of Immigration in 2025
description:
The CGLL is joined once again by Raju Mahajan, Esq., U.S. immigration attorney and founder of D.C.-based firm Raju Law, for a webinar on the the current legal environment surrounding immigration into the United States. This once-a-semester event introduces students to a subject matter expert, with knowledge gleaned from both theory and practice.
Register Here
Please note: Our virtual presentations are designed to foster interpersonal interaction, just as a face-to-face meeting would do. For that reason, no digital note-takers, recorders, or other AI-driven programs are permitted in our Zoom workshops. Thank you.
host: The Center for Graduate Life and Learning

name: Application Builder & LinkedIn/Resume Workshop
description:
Join us for our next informational meeting! This meeting is an informational workshop that allows you to learn more about building your resume, LinkedIn, and applications. These applications may be for post-grad schools such as medical schools, dental schools, nursing school, etc. We are here to help format your resume and build your application as a student!
This meeting will be held in Mebane Hall located in room 010. Reach out with any questions on how to get there!

name: Build Accessible Garden Beds for Seniors w/ Park CDC
description:
Join the Environment & Animals Committee in building garden beds for seniors living in affordable housing through the Park CDC organization! Also, the event might not run until 2pm, so be prepared for us to depart early if we get all of the work done before that time!
 
Please be sure to fill out all of the below forms before arriving at the event on Sunday morning:
Volunteer Application
Waiver and Release of Liability
Photo Release
- Coffee/Hot Chocolate will be provided
- Dress in layers and for the weather (As of right now, it looks to be feeling around 55-65 with little to no chance of rain, but check as the event gets closer)
- Please bring a snack or lunch item. We'll be doing some physical labor, so it's important to give yourself some energy to run off of!
If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to the Student Director for this event, Zack Lowell, via email: zlowell@charlotte.edu

name: Military and Veteran Resiliency Workshop
description:
Calling all graduate students with military connections, this one's for YOU! As part of Graduate Student Appreciation Week, we're hosting a wellness event designed to help you de-stress, de-focus, and recharge in the midst of your busy academic life. Whether you're a veteran, military spouse, or simply looking for a break, this event is open to all students! Prioritize your wellness, and celebrate your strength.
Refreshments will be served, space is limited so RSVP soon!

You can create a team of 8-10 players (7 on the field at once). It costs $50 per team to be able to play. Registration is mandatory and the sign up link can be found here: https://forms.gle/Gfhac1wQCHshkj349
All teams must register by April 8th. 
Come out and watch, compete, and support. Can’t wait to see you all there!

name: Springing into Post-Grad Life - Grad Student Support Space
description:
Session 3: Springing into Post-Grad Life
 
The graduate student support drop-in space was created to foster connection and community among graduate students and to help students learn strategies for supporting their holistic wellbeing. The drop-in space will be available monthly during the spring semester. The drop-in space does not require registration and is open to all graduate students. This is a collaboration between Counseling & Psychological Services and The Center for Graduate Life & Learning.

name: Art for the Heart
description:
Stressed? Overwhelmed? Take some time to unwind and make some art! Join us at the makerspace in Area 49, located in Atkins Library to sculpt or paint your troubles away, and keep what you create.
 
The first 50 people to rsvp will receive a wellness and destress gift bag, courtesy of The Center for Wellness Promotion! Plus, you can check out all the wonderful self-care items the library has to rent out, including projectors, noise machines, and sun lamps!
 
Join us and give yourself a break! RSVP Here: https://forms.gle/bFmQvn3dBo4me7K98
host: Graduate & Professional Student Government, J. Murrey Atkins Library

name: Swap Til Ya Drop
description:
Swap Til Ya Drop is a clothing swap event aimed at promoting sustainable fashion practices by encouraging students to exchange gently used clothing. The event will educate participants on the environmental impact of fast fashion and inspire a shift toward more eco-friendly lifestyle choices. Participants can bring their gently used clothes to donation areas located near tabling sites and Earth Month events around campus throughout April. 
The shop will be open from 1-4 pm on April 23rd in Belk Plaza for students to peruse and exchange tickets for clothing. 
Read the full donation instructions HERE.
DO Bring: 

Shirts/blouses
Pants (ex: khakis, jeans, joggers, cargo pants, etc.)
Shorts
Jackets
Accessories (ex: belts and purses/bags)

DON'T Bring:

Undergarments
Shoes
Stained or soiled items
Unintentionally ripped items 

Maximum # of Donated Items: 10

name: LEGENDARY GAME NIGHT
description: LEGENDARY GAME NIGHTS is the ultimate Friday night hangout where students come together to laugh, compete, and connect. Whether you're new on campus or just looking to meet fun, amazing people, Game Night is the perfect place to make new friends and be part of something bigger. No sign-up needed—just show up, bring good vibes, and get ready to make your college nights legendary. Hosted by the Legendary Club.
